In 2007, 2008 and 2009, ENVISAT ASAR data 179 scenes, covering the whole Heihe River Basin. Among them, there were 63 in 2007, 71 in 2008 and 45 in 2009. Imaging mode and acquisition time are respectively: app can select polarization mode from August 15, 2007 to December 23, 2007, from January 02, 2008 to December 202009-02-15, 2008 to September 06, 2009; imp imaging mode from June 19, 2009 to July 12, 2009; WSM wide mode from January 1, 2007 to December 302008-01-01, 2007 to November 28, 2008, from March 13, 2009 to May 22, 2009. 
The product level is L1B, which is amplitude data without geometric correction. 
The ENVISAT ASAR remote sensing data set of Heihe comprehensive remote sensing joint experiment is mainly obtained through the China EU "dragon plan" project (Project No.: 5322 and 5344); the WSM wide model data in 2007 and January 2008 are obtained from Professor Bob Su of ITC; the 8-view app can be purchased from the earth observation and digital earth center of Chinese Academy of Sciences.

background: Radar remote sensing has demonstrated its applicability to the retrieval of basin-scale soil moisture. The mechanism of radar backscattering from soils is complicated and strongly influenced by surface roughness. Surface soil moisture (mv) is important in agronomic, hydrological, and meteorological processes at all spatial scales. The ability of inferring mv using both active and passive microwave techniques has been intensively demonstrated. It is well known that space-borne microwave radiometers and scatterometers possess the advantage of high revisit capacity but are deficient in coarse spatial resolution. On the contrary, synthetic aperture radar (SAR) sensors have the capability to provide finer spatial resolution, on the order of tens of meters, meeting most spatial requirements for watershed management and hydrological applications. The advanced IEM (AIEM) improves the calculation accuracy of scattering coefficient by keeping the absolute phase term in Greens function which was neglected by IEM. In the IEM and AIEM, surface roughness is an essential input, thus, if only a single configuration (e.g., one polarization, one frequency) of radar data is available, roughness parameters should be known as a priori information in order to retrieve soil moisture using these models.
research objective: This study aims to simultaneously obtain surface roughness parameters (standard deviation of surface height σ and correlation length cl) along with soil moisture from multi-angular ASAR images by using a two-step retrieval scheme based on the AIEM.
challenges: The key challenge is the presence of vegetation cover, which significantly impacts the estimates of surface roughness and soil moisture. Field measuring surface roughness is very time-consuming and almost impractical at the regional scale. Moreover, appreciable inaccuracies may occur due to various deployments of instrumentation, sampling strategy, and the ambiguous scale effect during field campaigns and data post-processing.
methods: The method firstly used a semi-empirical relationship that relates the roughness slope, Zs (Zs = σ2 /cl) and the difference in backscattering coefficient (Δσ) from two ASAR images acquired with different incidence angles. Then, the deduced roughness parameters were used for the retrieval of soil moisture in association with the AIEM. An evaluation of the proposed method was performed in an experimental area in the middle stream of the Heihe River Basin, where the Watershed Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (WATER) was taken place.
dataset: The study was carried out at one of the W A TER foci experimental areas (FEAs). Linze grassland (LZG; 100 ◦04 ′ E, 39 ◦15 ′ N), which covers an area of 2 × 2 km 2 , locates in Linze county, Zhangye city in the middle stream of the Heihe River Basin. During the field campaigns conducted in the intensive observation period (IOP) from May to August 2008, five experimental sites (ESs), each 360 × 360 m 2 in size, were established. Ground truths, including soil moisture, land surface temperature (T), and bulk density, were collected at all five ESs concurrently with radar acquisitions. ASAR operates at C-band (5.3 GHz) and was launched onboard ENVISAT in 2002. In this investigation, three contiguous ASAR images in alternating polarization precision (APP) modes with different incidence angles ranging from IS1 (18.4 ◦) to IS7 (43.9 ◦) were acquired.
findings: It is demonstrated that the proposed method is feasible to achieve reliable estimation of soil water content.

background: Soil moisture is a variable that plays a leading role in surface water and energy balance. The traditional point measurements can just provide a soil moisture distribution in a limited area. The hydrologic models can simulate the soil moisture variation in large spatial and temporal scales. However, the uncertainty in initial model state, model physical parameters, meteorological forcing variables and model equations brings much error in the soil moisture estimation. Many researchers suggested that the most promising approach for estimating soil moisture is the integration of remote sensing surface soil moisture data and a hydrologic model (Kostove and Jackson, 1993). Many researches have been carried out on optimizing a computational model through minimizing the difference between the observation and model simulation results by the re-parameterization (Jarlan et al., 2005; Yang et al., 2009) or re-initialization (Heathman et al., 2003; Huang et al., 2008) of the computational model separately. The re-parameterization approach can improve the model state variables by adjusting uncertain parameters. Since some parameters can hardly be obtained by field measurements, they are often estimated from the experiences or references, which brings much uncertainty to the model parameters. The re-initialization approach does not attribute the simulation errors to the uncertainties of the initial conditions, model parameters or model physical equations. It can adjust the state variables directly and it adopts the updated state variables as the initial field to re-initialize the model. The most effective and popular re-initialization approach is Ensemble Kalman Filter (EnKF).
research objective: This research developed a one-dimensional soil moisture assimilation scheme based on the Ensemble Kalman Filter (EnKF) and Genetic Algorithm (GA). In this research, the assimilation scheme combined the EnKF and GA as the assimilation algorithm and it could calibrate the model parameters and model initial state synthetically. This paper proposes a one-dimensional soil moisture assimilation scheme combining the EnKF and GA, which has been illuminated by the assimilation experiment carried out in the Heihe River Basin in Northwest China in 2008.
challenges: There is much uncertainty in the assimilation process, which affects the assimilation results. There is much uncertainty in the model initial state and model parameters in the hydrologic modeling, which brings much error to the soil moisture simulation. It is difficult to develop the adjoint model for the original one to evaluate the derivatives of the cost function with respect to control variables, which are composed of state variables and model parameters to be estimated. It is complicated to develop the adjoint model in practice, which posed many limitations to its application (Qin et al., 2007).
methods: In this assimilation scheme, the soil moisture was taken as the combination point of the hydrologic model and the backscattering model. The DHSVM was coupled with a semi-empirical backscattering model (Oh) to simulate backscattering coefficients. When the ASAR data were available, a cost function was set up based on the gap between the backscattering coefficients from ASAR observation and the backscattering coefficients from the simulations. Then the EnKF was used to optimize the state variables. If the cost function was higher than twice the ASAR observation noises, the simulation was treated as unacceptable. Then the cost function was minimized by the GA approach. The sensitive parameters of the DHSVM were re-parameterized. The simulations were divided into acceptable and unacceptable cases. The EnKF and GA were used to re-initialize and re-parameterize the simulation process. The assimilation experiment was carried out in the Heihe River Basin, Northwest China.
dataset: The Heihe River Basin, located in the arid area of Northwest China, is the second largest inland river basin, with an area of 116 000 km2 and an average annual precipitation of 108 mm. The ASAR images were used as observation data. ASAR images were acquired for several dates and different polarizations with incidence angles between 10º and 60º, operating in C band. The spatial resolution of ASAR is about 12.5 m × 12.5 m. The spatial resolution of the DHSVM simulation was 30 m, so the spatial resolution of ASAR was resampled into 30 m by the bilinear interpolation method.
findings: The results obtained indicate that this assimilation scheme is practical and it can improve the accuracy of soil moisture estimation significantly. The result shows that the model estimate of surface soil moisture was improved by being assimilated with the ASAR data. Additionally, the data assimilation improves the DHSVM model outputs which are more close to the actual values.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a dataset that illustrates the integration of remote sensing and hydrologic models for soil moisture estimation?
Example.Answer: The dataset from the Heihe River Basin experiment, which used ASAR images and the DHSVM model, demonstrates the integration of remote sensing data with hydrologic modeling to improve soil moisture estimation through data assimilation techniques like the Ensemble Kalman Filter (EnKF) and Genetic Algorithm (GA).

Example.Question: What is an example of a data collection method that addresses the challenge of retrieving soil moisture in the presence of vegetation cover?
Example.Answer: An example is the two-step retrieval scheme based on the Advanced Integral Equation Model (AIEM) using multi-angular ASAR images, which was implemented to deduce surface roughness parameters and retrieve soil moisture in areas with vegetation cover in the Heihe River Basin.

Interpretation.Question: What are the implications of using multi-angular ASAR images for the simultaneous retrieval of surface roughness and soil moisture in terms of data processing and interpretation challenges?
Interpretation.Answer: Using multi-angular ASAR images involves interpreting complex radar backscattering influenced by surface roughness and soil moisture. The approach requires a two-step retrieval scheme based on the advanced IEM (AIEM) to derive roughness parameters, which are then used for soil moisture retrieval. The main challenges include accounting for vegetation cover, which affects the accuracy of estimates, and managing the time-consuming nature of field measurements needed for validation.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways can the spatial resolution differences between ASAR data and hydrologic model simulations be addressed to ensure accurate soil moisture estimation?
Interpretation.Answer: Spatial resolution differences can be addressed by resampling ASAR data to match the resolution of hydrologic model simulations. For example, ASAR data with a resolution of 12.5 m × 12.5 m can be interpolated to 30 m to align with the Digital Hydrology Soil-Vegetation Model (DHSVM) simulation resolution. This resampling helps in reducing discrepancies and improves the integration of remote sensing data with model simulations, leading to more accurate soil moisture estimates.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the underlying reasons that surface roughness significantly impacts the estimates of soil moisture in radar remote sensing data collection methods?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Surface roughness is a critical factor in radar remote sensing because it affects radar backscattering from soils. This complexity is amplified by the presence of vegetation cover, making it challenging to accurately estimate soil moisture. Additionally, field measurement of surface roughness is time-consuming and impractical on a regional scale, leading to potential inaccuracies due to variations in instrumentation deployments and sampling strategies.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is there considerable uncertainty in the model parameters and initial state during the soil moisture assimilation process?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The uncertainty in model parameters and initial state arises from the difficulty in obtaining precise field measurements and the inherent variability in hydrologic modeling. This leads to errors in soil moisture simulation. Furthermore, developing an adjoint model to evaluate derivatives of the cost function with respect to control variables is complex, posing limitations on its practical application.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the feasibility of using synthetic aperture radar (SAR) sensors for soil moisture retrieval at a basin scale, despite challenges associated with vegetation cover?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Synthetic aperture radar (SAR) sensors are feasible for soil moisture retrieval at a basin scale due to their capability to provide fine spatial resolution, meeting most spatial requirements for watershed management and hydrological applications. The advanced IEM (AIEM) model improves the calculation accuracy of scattering coefficients, which is crucial given that surface roughness, impacted by vegetation cover, is an essential input for these models.

Causal Consequence.Question: What causal consequences can arise from integrating radar remote sensing data with models for soil moisture estimation?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Integrating radar remote sensing data with models for soil moisture estimation can significantly improve the accuracy of soil moisture estimation. By combining remote sensing data with hydrologic models, researchers can overcome the limitations of traditional point measurements and address uncertainties in initial model states and parameters, leading to more reliable soil moisture distribution predictions over large spatial and temporal scales.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential outcomes of using a two-step retrieval scheme based on the AIEM for estimating soil moisture and surface roughness parameters?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using a two-step retrieval scheme based on the AIEM for estimating soil moisture and surface roughness parameters can lead to reliable estimations of soil water content. By utilizing multi-angular radar images, this approach can deduce roughness parameters and subsequently retrieve soil moisture accurately, even in the presence of challenges such as vegetation cover.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary objective behind utilizing multi-angular ASAR images in the simultaneous retrieval of surface roughness and soil moisture parameters?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objective is to obtain surface roughness parameters along with soil moisture using a two-step retrieval scheme based on the AIEM, which is crucial for understanding soil moisture distribution and its role in hydrological processes.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the rationale for employing the Ensemble Kalman Filter (EnKF) and Genetic Algorithm (GA) in developing a soil moisture assimilation scheme?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The rationale for using the EnKF and GA is to optimize the state variables and calibrate model parameters and initial state synthetically, which enhances the accuracy of soil moisture estimation by reducing uncertainties in the modeling process.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are involved in using multi-angular ASAR images to simultaneously retrieve surface roughness parameters and soil moisture?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The procedure involves a two-step retrieval scheme using the advanced Integral Equation Model (AIEM). First, a semi-empirical relationship is employed to relate the roughness slope (Zs) and the difference in backscattering coefficient (Δσ) from two ASAR images acquired with different incidence angles. The deduced roughness parameters are then used for retrieving soil moisture in association with the AIEM.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can the Ensemble Kalman Filter and Genetic Algorithm be integrated into a soil moisture assimilation scheme for improving hydrological model accuracy?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The integration involves using the Ensemble Kalman Filter (EnKF) to optimize state variables and the Genetic Algorithm (GA) to minimize a cost function based on the gap between simulated and observed backscattering coefficients. If the cost function exceeds twice the ASAR observation noise, it is treated as unacceptable, prompting GA to further re-parameterize sensitive parameters. This combined approach allows for simultaneous calibration of model parameters and initial states, enhancing the accuracy of soil moisture estimation.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the specific methods used to address the challenges of measuring surface roughness and soil moisture under vegetation cover in radar remote sensing?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To address these challenges, the method involves using ASAR images with different incidence angles to derive roughness parameters through a semi-empirical relationship. The deduced roughness parameters are then employed in conjunction with AIEM to retrieve soil moisture. This approach helps overcome the difficulty of field measuring surface roughness and the impact of vegetation cover on estimates.

Enablement.Question: What methodologies enable the accurate retrieval of soil moisture and surface roughness parameters using radar remote sensing in basin-scale applications?
Enablement.Answer: The methodologies involve using a two-step retrieval scheme based on the advanced IEM (AIEM), which includes a semi-empirical relationship that relates surface roughness parameters and differences in backscattering coefficients. This approach requires multi-angular radar data and considers vegetation cover impacts.

Enablement.Question: How does the integration of remote sensing data with hydrologic models improve soil moisture estimation in large spatial and temporal scales?
Enablement.Answer: The integration involves using remote sensing surface soil moisture data combined with a hydrologic model and optimization techniques like the Ensemble Kalman Filter (EnKF) and Genetic Algorithm (GA) to calibrate model parameters and initial states, thus improving simulation accuracy.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be significant challenges in accurately estimating soil moisture and surface roughness from radar remote sensing data in regions with vegetation cover?
Expectation.Answer: The presence of vegetation cover significantly impacts the estimates of surface roughness and soil moisture. Vegetation can interfere with radar signals, leading to inaccuracies in the data. Additionally, field measuring surface roughness is time-consuming and impractical at large scales, and various factors like instrumentation deployment and sampling strategies can introduce errors during data collection and post-processing.

Expectation.Question: What expectations might researchers have when integrating remote sensing surface soil moisture data with hydrologic models, and why might these expectations not always be met?
Expectation.Answer: Researchers may expect that integrating remote sensing data with hydrologic models will improve soil moisture estimation by reducing errors related to model state variables and parameters. However, uncertainties in model initial states, physical parameters, and meteorological forcing can introduce significant errors. Additionally, developing adjoint models to evaluate derivatives is complicated and can limit practical application, leading to unmet expectations.

Expectation.Question: Why might a dataset require resampling or interpolation for consistency with simulation models, and what impact could this have on the interpretation of results?
Expectation.Answer: A dataset might require resampling or interpolation to match the spatial resolution of simulation models, as seen when ASAR images with a spatial resolution of about 12.5 m × 12.5 m are resampled to 30 m to align with the DHSVM simulation. This process can impact the interpretation of results by potentially introducing interpolation errors or smoothing effects that could affect the accuracy of the data and the subsequent analysis.

Judgmental.Question: How effective do you think the use of multi-angular ASAR images is in simultaneously retrieving surface roughness parameters and soil moisture?
Judgmental.Answer: The use of multi-angular ASAR images is considered effective for simultaneously retrieving surface roughness parameters and soil moisture by employing a two-step retrieval scheme based on the AIEM. This approach allows for the extraction of essential surface characteristics by utilizing different incidence angles, which provides a feasible method for achieving reliable soil moisture estimation.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, what are the main challenges when integrating remote sensing data with hydrologic models for soil moisture estimation?
Judgmental.Answer: The main challenges when integrating remote sensing data with hydrologic models for soil moisture estimation include dealing with uncertainties in model initial states and parameters, as well as the difficulty in developing adjoint models to evaluate derivatives of cost functions. These challenges can introduce significant errors and limitations in the estimation process, necessitating sophisticated assimilation techniques such as the Ensemble Kalman Filter combined with Genetic Algorithms to improve accuracy.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how surface roughness parameters can be derived from multi-angular ASAR images.
Assertion.Answer: Surface roughness parameters, such as the standard deviation of surface height and correlation length, are obtained by using a two-step retrieval scheme based on the Advanced Integral Equation Model (AIEM). The method involves using a semi-empirical relationship that relates the roughness slope and the difference in backscattering coefficient from two ASAR images acquired with different incidence angles.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about how the integration of remote sensing data with hydrologic models can enhance soil moisture estimation?
Assertion.Answer: The integration is achieved through a soil moisture assimilation scheme that combines the Ensemble Kalman Filter (EnKF) and Genetic Algorithm (GA). This scheme allows for the calibration of model parameters and initial states by optimizing the gap between observed and simulated backscattering coefficients, thus improving the accuracy of soil moisture estimation.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of why vegetation cover poses a significant challenge in estimating soil moisture and surface roughness.
Assertion.Answer: Vegetation cover affects the radar backscattering signal, making it difficult to accurately estimate soil moisture and surface roughness. It introduces variability and noise that can obscure the radar signal reflecting from the soil, hence complicating the retrieval of accurate surface parameters from the radar data.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the challenges encountered in estimating soil moisture and surface roughness from radar remote sensing data, considering the impact of vegetation cover.
Request/Directive.Answer: The challenges in estimating soil moisture and surface roughness include the significant impact of vegetation cover, which complicates the retrieval process. Field measures of surface roughness are time-consuming and impractical at regional scales, and inaccuracies may arise from instrumentation deployment, sampling strategies, and scale effects. These factors make it difficult to achieve accurate estimates without prior knowledge of roughness parameters.
